Hit BBC show Sherlock could come to an end soon after the show’s boss admitted they didn’t want the drama to “go past” when it should finish in terms of quality. 
The opening episode of the current series attracted over eight million viewers and it continues to be a huge global hit. 
But at a Bafta screening for episode two in Cardiff - held on Sunday morning ahead of the episode - co-creator Steven Moffat admitted the third episode of the series will be a “grand old finale” type of ending, prompting questions from the audience about the possibility this could be the last ever series. No more Sherlock? (Photo: BBC) We want more Sherlock, right? (Photo: BBC) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now The dark and dramatic trailer for the new Sherlock Share this video Watch Next Read More 
Moffat said: “Its a big loud note at the end. I didn’t mean in the sense I will never do Sherlock Holmes again. 
“Honestly, we don’t know, that is the honest truth. 
“We still haven’t sat down and worked out what we do. 
“We are incredibly aware that this is extraordinary in terms of scale. 
“We don’t want to let go of it because it is a wonderful thing but we don’t want to keep it going past the time that it should stop.” Sherlock (Photo: BBC) (Photo: BBC) Read More Sherlock shock as Watson's wife is KILLED when she takes bullet for Holmes in dramatic series opener 
Whilst Moffat and co-creator Mark Gatiss have their own other writing commitments, the drama’s two main stars are amongst the most in-demand British actors. 
Both Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman are now huge stars Stateside meaning they have dozens of work offers and have had to fit Sherlock in around other film and TV work. Like us on Facebook
